perturbation.original_text: All such materials shall be submitted to Chase at least seven (7) days prior to the date of first intended use.  Chase will notify Affiliate of its approval or disapproval of such materials within five (5) business days of its receipt of all information required to be submitted.
perturbation.changed_text: All such materials shall be submitted to Chase at least two (2) days prior to the date of first intended use. Chase will notify Affiliate of its approval or disapproval of such materials within ten (10) business days of its receipt of all information required to be submitted.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a reasonable timeframe for submitting materials for approval and receiving a response. Reducing the submission timeframe to 2 days places an undue burden on the affiliate to produce materials quickly and is not commercially reasonable. Extending Chase's review period to 10 business days would likely cause operational bottlenecks and conflict with affiliate marketing campaign launch timelines. Such delays can lead to lost revenue and missed marketing opportunities. Therefore, the change is unreasonable and contradicts established business practices that necessitate quick turnaround times.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of contract, violation of good faith and fair dealing

perturbation.original_text: Either Affiliate or Chase may terminate this Agreement at any time, with or without cause, by giving the other party written or e-mail notice of termination. At the time of termination, any links to Chase’s Website must be removed immediately. Affiliate will continue to receive Commission payments for all Approved Accounts placed during the term of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Either Affiliate or Chase may terminate this Agreement at any time, with or without cause, without any notice of termination. At the time of termination, any links to Chase’s Website must be removed at Chase’s discretion. Affiliate will not receive Commission payments for any Approved Accounts placed during the term of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The changes to this section are designed to conflict with contract law principles and potentially state laws regarding termination notices and payment of earned commissions. Removing the requirement for any notice of termination is problematic, as many jurisdictions require reasonable notice, especially when a contract has been ongoing for a substantial period. Further, denying the affiliate commission payments for approved accounts placed during the term of the agreement contradicts the reasonable expectation that services rendered should be compensated. This is especially pertinent if the affiliate has incurred costs in promoting Chase's products or services. This clause could be deemed unconscionable or a violation of fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of contract, violation of good faith and fair dealing, state wage laws

perturbation.original_text: Chase reserves the right to change any and all of the terms and conditions in this Agreement, at any time and in its sole discretion, by posting a new agreement on its Website. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the amount of Commissions, the definition of Approved Accounts, and all other provisions of this Agreement are subject to change without notice other than posting such information on the Chase Website.
perturbation.changed_text: Chase reserves the right to change any and all of the terms and conditions in this Agreement, at any time and in its sole discretion, without any notice. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the amount of Commissions, the definition of Approved Accounts, and all other provisions of this Agreement are subject to change without any notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires Chase to post a new agreement on its website when changes are made, this modified text removes that requirement, so that Chase does not need to provide any notice before changing terms of service. This type of unilateral change is against contract law which requires an amendement to have both side's agreement. In this case, Chase has full control.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of contract, violation of good faith and fair dealing, contract law
